channel.title: Last Day - NEW & UPDATE
channel.description: All NEW and UPDATE articles from the last day with enhanced metadata

item.title: NEW: URGENT: CISA Orders 7-Day Patch for Actively Exploited FortiWeb Zero-Day
item.description:
Headline: URGENT: CISA Orders 7-Day Patch for Actively Exploited FortiWeb Zero-Day

Summary:
Fortinet has disclosed a critical OS command injection zero-day vulnerability, CVE-2025-58034, in its FortiWeb Web Application Firewall (WAF) that is being actively exploited in the wild. The flaw allows an authenticated attacker to execute arbitrary commands on the underlying system. In response to observed attacks, the U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added the vulnerability to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog and issued an emergency directive mandating federal agencies apply patches within an accelerated seven-day window, by November 25, 2025. Researchers have detected approximately 2,000 attacks leveraging the flaw and warn it could potentially be chained with a recently disclosed authentication bypass vulnerability (CVE-2025-64446) to achieve unauthenticated remote code execution.

Severity: Critical

Categories: Vulnerability, Patch Management, Cyberattack

Article Type: Advisory

Reading Time: 5 minutes

Meta Description: Fortinet discloses and CISA mandates urgent patching for CVE-2025-58034, a critical OS command injection zero-day in FortiWeb WAFs that is under active exploitation. Learn about the risks and mitigation steps.

Article Slug: cisa-mandates-7-day-patch-for-actively-exploited-fortinet-fortiweb-zero-day-cve-2025-58034

Published Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: Patch Now: Microsoft Fixes Actively Exploited Windows Kernel Zero-Day
item.description:
Headline: Patch Now: Microsoft Fixes Actively Exploited Windows Kernel Zero-Day

Summary:
As part of its November 2025 Patch Tuesday release, Microsoft has addressed 63 security vulnerabilities, including a high-severity zero-day flaw in the Windows Kernel (CVE-2025-62215) that is confirmed to be under active exploitation. The vulnerability is a local privilege escalation (LPE) bug with a CVSS score of 7.0, allowing an attacker who has already gained initial access to a system to elevate their privileges to SYSTEM level. Such flaws are critical components in post-exploitation attack chains, enabling threat actors to take full control of a compromised machine. The update also fixes 16 remote code execution (RCE) vulnerabilities and numerous other flaws across the Microsoft product suite. Immediate patching is strongly recommended for all Windows users.

Severity: Critical

Categories: Vulnerability, Patch Management, Threat Intelligence

Article Type: Advisory

Reading Time: 5 minutes

Meta Description: Microsoft's November 2025 Patch Tuesday fixes 63 vulnerabilities, including CVE-2025-62215, a Windows Kernel zero-day that is actively exploited for privilege escalation. Details on the flaw and mitigation.

Article Slug: microsoft-patches-actively-exploited-windows-kernel-zero-day-cve-2025-62215-in-november-patch-tuesday

Published Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: Google Chrome Zero-Day Exploited in Wild, CISA Mandates Urgent Patch
item.description:
Headline: Google Chrome Zero-Day Exploited in Wild, CISA Mandates Urgent Patch

Summary:
Google has patched a high-severity zero-day vulnerability in its Chrome web browser, CVE-2025-13223, which is being actively exploited in the wild. The flaw is a type confusion error in the V8 JavaScript engine that can be leveraged by an attacker for remote code execution (RCE) simply by luring a victim to a malicious website. Following Google's confirmation of in-the-wild exploitation, the U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) promptly added the vulnerability to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog, mandating that federal agencies apply the update by December 10, 2025. The vulnerability affects Chrome on all major desktop platforms (Windows, macOS, and Linux) and other Chromium-based browsers.

Severity: Critical

Categories: Vulnerability, Cyberattack, Patch Management

Article Type: Advisory

Reading Time: 5 minutes

Meta Description: CISA warns of an actively exploited Google Chrome zero-day vulnerability, CVE-2025-13223, a type confusion flaw in the V8 engine allowing for remote code execution. Update to version 131.0.6778.72 or later immediately.

Article Slug: cisa-warns-of-actively-exploited-google-chrome-zero-day-cve-2025-13223

Published Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: Sinobi Ransomware Strikes US Manufacturer and Indian Tech Firm
item.description:
Headline: Sinobi Ransomware Strikes US Manufacturer and Indian Tech Firm

Summary:
The 'sinobi' ransomware group has claimed responsibility for two recent cyberattacks targeting organizations in the United States and India. The victims are Croft, a U.S.-based window and door manufacturer, and CHANGEPOND, an enterprise software company headquartered in Chennai, India. Both breaches were discovered on November 19, 2025, occurring within minutes of each other. These incidents underscore the global reach and indiscriminate targeting of ransomware operators, affecting diverse sectors including manufacturing and technology. The attacks highlight the persistent threat posed by ransomware and the importance of robust cybersecurity defenses.

Severity: High

Categories: Ransomware, Threat Actor, Cyberattack

Article Type: NewsArticle

Reading Time: 4 minutes

Meta Description: The 'sinobi' ransomware group has claimed responsibility for cyberattacks on US manufacturer Croft and Indian software company CHANGEPOND, demonstrating a global, cross-industry threat.

Article Slug: sinobi-ransomware-group-attacks-us-manufacturer-croft-and-indian-tech-firm-changepond

Published Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: PA Attorney General Confirms Massive Data Breach by Inc Ransom
item.description:
Headline: PA Attorney General Confirms Massive Data Breach by Inc Ransom

Summary:
The Pennsylvania Office of the Attorney General (OAG) has officially confirmed it was the victim of a significant ransomware attack orchestrated by the 'Inc Ransom' group. The attack, which occurred in August 2025, disrupted the agency's operations for three weeks. The threat actors claim to have exfiltrated 5.7 terabytes of highly sensitive data, including Social Security numbers, medical details, and investigative files. The initial access vector is believed to be the exploitation of the 'CitrixBleed2' vulnerability (CVE-2025-5777) on the agency's Citrix NetScaler appliances. The FBI is now investigating the incident, and the OAG is in the process of notifying affected individuals.

Severity: Critical

Categories: Data Breach, Ransomware, Vulnerability

Article Type: NewsArticle

Reading Time: 5 minutes

Meta Description: The Pennsylvania Office of the Attorney General confirms it was hit by the Inc Ransom group, who exploited CVE-2025-5777 (CitrixBleed2) to steal 5.7 TB of sensitive data and disrupt operations for weeks.

Article Slug: pennsylvania-attorney-general-confirms-major-data-breach-by-inc-ransom-group

Published Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: CISA and Partners Release Guide to Combat Bulletproof Hosting
item.description:
Headline: CISA and Partners Release Guide to Combat Bulletproof Hosting

Summary:
The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA), along with the FBI, NSA, and international partners, has published a comprehensive guide to help network defenders and Internet Service Providers (ISPs) combat the threat of bulletproof hosting (BPH) providers. These services knowingly lease infrastructure to cybercriminals for a wide range of malicious activities, including ransomware, phishing, and malware distribution. The guide, 'Bulletproof Defense,' provides actionable recommendations for filtering malicious traffic, enhancing network monitoring, and improving intelligence sharing to disrupt the criminal ecosystem that relies on BPH for anonymity and resilience.

Severity: Informational

Categories: Policy and Compliance, Threat Intelligence, Security Operations

Article Type: Advisory

Reading Time: 4 minutes

Meta Description: CISA, in partnership with the FBI and NSA, has published a new guide to help organizations mitigate risks from bulletproof hosting (BPH) providers that support cybercrime.

Article Slug: cisa-and-fbi-release-guide-to-combat-malicious-bulletproof-hosting-providers

Published Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: AI-Driven Attacks Explode: Malware Emails Spike 131%, Report Finds
item.description:
Headline: AI-Driven Attacks Explode: Malware Emails Spike 131%, Report Finds

Summary:
A new cybersecurity report from Hornetsecurity highlights a dramatic increase in AI-powered cyberattacks throughout 2025. The analysis of over 72 billion emails revealed that the volume of malware-laden emails grew by 131% year-over-year, while phishing and scam attempts also rose significantly. The report attributes this surge to threat actors' adoption of generative AI, which enables the creation of highly convincing and sophisticated malicious content at scale. In response, 77% of CISOs now view AI-generated phishing as a major threat, and 68% of organizations have invested in AI-powered defenses, signaling a new 'arms race' in cybersecurity.

Severity: Medium

Categories: Threat Intelligence, Phishing, Malware

Article Type: Report

Reading Time: 4 minutes

Meta Description: A 2025 Hornetsecurity report finds that AI-driven cyberattacks are surging, with malware-laden emails increasing by 131% as threat actors weaponize generative AI for more sophisticated phishing campaigns.

Article Slug: ai-powered-cyberattacks-surge-malware-emails-up-131-percent-report

Published Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: CISA Issues 6 New ICS Advisories for Schneider Electric, Shelly, METZ CONNECT
item.description:
Headline: CISA Issues 6 New ICS Advisories for Schneider Electric, Shelly, METZ CONNECT

Summary:
On November 19, 2025, the U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) released six new Industrial Control Systems (ICS) advisories, highlighting multiple vulnerabilities in products from Schneider Electric, Shelly, and METZ CONNECT. The alerts affect a range of operational technology (OT) products, including SCADA systems and power monitoring devices. Four of the advisories are for Schneider Electric products like EcoStruxure and PowerChute. CISA urges administrators in critical infrastructure and manufacturing sectors to review the advisories and apply the recommended mitigations to prevent potential exploitation.

Severity: Medium

Categories: Industrial Control Systems, Vulnerability, Patch Management

Article Type: Advisory

Reading Time: 4 minutes

Meta Description: CISA has released six new Industrial Control Systems (ICS) advisories detailing vulnerabilities in products from Schneider Electric, Shelly, and METZ CONNECT. Critical infrastructure operators should review and mitigate.

Article Slug: cisa-publishes-six-new-advisories-for-industrial-control-systems-ics

Published Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: CISA Releases "Be Air Aware" Guides to Combat Drone Threats
item.description:
Headline: CISA Releases "Be Air Aware" Guides to Combat Drone Threats

Summary:
As part of Critical Infrastructure Security and Resilience Month, the U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has released three new guides under its "Be Air Aware™" campaign. These resources are designed to help critical infrastructure owners and operators understand, assess, and mitigate the growing security risks posed by Unmanned Aircraft Systems (UAS), or drones. The guides provide actionable information on detecting suspicious drone activity, implementing detection technologies, and safely handling downed aircraft, aiming to integrate aerial threat considerations into existing security plans.

Severity: Informational

Categories: Policy and Compliance, Industrial Control Systems, Security Operations

Article Type: Advisory

Reading Time: 4 minutes

Meta Description: CISA's new 'Be Air Aware' campaign provides three new guides to help critical infrastructure owners and operators defend against the growing security threats posed by drones (UAS).

Article Slug: cisa-launches-be-air-aware-guides-to-defend-critical-infrastructure-from-drone-threats

Published Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: New 'Nova Stealer' Malware Targets macOS Crypto Wallets
item.description:
Headline: New 'Nova Stealer' Malware Targets macOS Crypto Wallets

Summary:
A new information-stealing malware, dubbed 'Nova Stealer,' has been discovered actively targeting Apple macOS users. The malware's primary goal is the exfiltration of sensitive data, with a specific focus on cryptocurrency wallets. Nova Stealer operates as a trojan, infecting systems by replacing legitimate, installed applications with malicious versions. When a user launches the compromised application, the malware activates in the background to search for and steal wallet files and other valuable information. This discovery underscores the increasing trend of threat actors developing malware for the macOS platform, challenging the perception of it being inherently more secure than Windows.

Severity: High

Categories: Malware, Threat Intelligence, Mobile Security

Article Type: NewsArticle

Reading Time: 4 minutes

Meta Description: Security researchers have identified 'Nova Stealer,' a new information-stealing malware that targets macOS users by trojanizing legitimate applications to steal cryptocurrency wallets and data.

Article Slug: new-nova-stealer-malware-targets-macos-users-for-cryptocurrency-wallets

Published Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: Google Scrambles to Patch 7th Actively Exploited Chrome Zero-Day of 2025
item.description:
Headline: Google Scrambles to Patch 7th Actively Exploited Chrome Zero-Day of 2025

Summary:
Google has released an emergency security update for its Chrome web browser to fix a high-severity zero-day vulnerability, CVE-2025-13223, which is confirmed to be actively exploited in the wild. The flaw is a type confusion weakness in the V8 JavaScript engine, allowing attackers to achieve remote code execution by luring users to a malicious website. This marks the seventh zero-day patched in Chrome this year. The update also addresses a second V8 flaw, CVE-2025-13224. Users are urged to update their browsers immediately to version 142.0.7444.175/.176, and users of other Chromium-based browsers should expect similar patches.

Severity: Critical

Categories: Vulnerability, Patch Management, Cyberattack

Article Type: Advisory

Keywords: CVE-2025-13223, Google Chrome zero-day, V8 vulnerability, actively exploited, remote code execution, browser security, emergency patch, Chromium exploit

Reading Time: 6 minutes

Meta Description: Google has issued an emergency patch for CVE-2025-13223, a high-severity type confusion zero-day vulnerability in the Chrome V8 engine that is being actively exploited. Learn about the flaw and how to mitigate it.

Article Slug: google-patches-actively-exploited-chrome-v8-zero-day-cve-2025-13223

Published Date: Wed, 19 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Wed, 19 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Wed, 19 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: Inc Ransom Cripples PA Attorney General's Office, Exfiltrates 5.7 TB of Data
item.description:
Headline: Inc Ransom Cripples PA Attorney General's Office, Exfiltrates 5.7 TB of Data

Summary:
The Pennsylvania Office of the Attorney General (OAG) has confirmed it suffered a severe data breach orchestrated by the Inc Ransom ransomware group. The attackers exploited the 'CitrixBleed2' vulnerability (CVE-2025-5777) to gain initial access and subsequently exfiltrated 5.7 terabytes of highly sensitive data. The stolen information includes Social Security numbers, medical details, and confidential investigative files. The attack, which occurred in August 2025, caused a three-week operational disruption for the agency's 1,200 staff members. The OAG has refused to pay the ransom and is working with the FBI on the investigation.

Severity: High

Categories: Ransomware, Data Breach, Vulnerability

Article Type: NewsArticle

Keywords: Inc Ransom, Pennsylvania Attorney General data breach, CVE-2025-5777, CitrixBleed2 exploit, ransomware attack, government data breach, double extortion

Reading Time: 7 minutes

Meta Description: Learn about the major data breach at the Pennsylvania Office of the Attorney General, where the Inc Ransom group exploited CVE-2025-5777 to steal 5.7 TB of sensitive data, including SSNs and medical information.

Article Slug: pennsylvania-attorney-general-confirms-major-data-breach-by-inc-ransomware

Published Date: Wed, 19 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Wed, 19 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Wed, 19 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: US, UK, and Australia Sanction Russian Bulletproof Hosting Network Aiding Ransomware
item.description:
Headline: US, UK, and Australia Sanction Russian Bulletproof Hosting Network Aiding Ransomware

Summary:
In a coordinated action, the United States, United Kingdom, and Australia have sanctioned Media Land, LLC, a Russian bulletproof hosting provider, along with its network of related entities and key individuals. This infrastructure is accused of providing essential services to a wide range of global cybercriminals, including malware distributors, phishing operators, and ransomware groups like the notorious LockBit gang. The sanctions aim to disrupt the foundational services that enable cybercrime by targeting the providers who knowingly support malicious operations. The action highlights a strategic international effort to dismantle the cybercrime economy.

Severity: Medium

Categories: Policy and Compliance, Threat Actor, Regulatory

Article Type: NewsArticle

Keywords: OFAC sanctions, Media Land LLC, Russian cybercrime, bulletproof hosting, LockBit infrastructure, cybercrime sanctions, Aleksandr Volosovik

Reading Time: 6 minutes

Meta Description: The U.S., U.K., and Australia have jointly sanctioned Russian bulletproof hosting provider Media Land, LLC for facilitating ransomware and other cybercrime. Learn about the impact of this international action.

Article Slug: us-uk-australia-sanction-russian-bulletproof-hosting-network-media-land

Published Date: Wed, 19 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Wed, 19 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Wed, 19 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: DoorDash Hit by Data Breach After Employee Falls for Social Engineering Scam
item.description:
Headline: DoorDash Hit by Data Breach After Employee Falls for Social Engineering Scam

Summary:
Food delivery giant DoorDash has disclosed a data breach that occurred after an employee was targeted by a social engineering scam. The unauthorized access allowed a third party to view the personal information of customers, delivery personnel ('Dashers'), and merchants. The compromised data includes names, email addresses, phone numbers, and physical addresses. DoorDash has stated that sensitive financial data and government IDs were not accessed. The company has secured its systems, notified affected parties, and established a call center to address user concerns.

Severity: Medium

Categories: Data Breach, Phishing, Cloud Security

Article Type: NewsArticle

Keywords: DoorDash data breach, social engineering, phishing attack, customer data leak, cybersecurity incident, employee scam

Reading Time: 6 minutes

Meta Description: Food delivery service DoorDash has disclosed a data breach affecting customers, Dashers, and merchants after an employee fell victim to a social engineering scam. Learn what data was exposed.

Article Slug: doordash-discloses-data-breach-after-employee-social-engineering-scam

Published Date: Wed, 19 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Wed, 19 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Wed, 19 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: CISA Adds Actively Exploited Fortinet FortiWeb Flaw to KEV Catalog
item.description:
Headline: CISA Adds Actively Exploited Fortinet FortiWeb Flaw to KEV Catalog

Summary:
The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added a critical OS command injection vulnerability in Fortinet's FortiWeb products, CVE-2025-58034, to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog. Citing evidence of active exploitation, CISA has mandated a one-week remediation deadline for Federal Civilian Executive Branch (FCEB) agencies under Binding Operational Directive (BOD) 22-01. The vulnerability allows attackers to execute arbitrary commands on affected devices. CISA strongly urges all organizations using FortiWeb to prioritize patching this flaw to mitigate the threat.

Severity: Critical

Categories: Vulnerability, Patch Management, Cyberattack

Article Type: Advisory

Keywords: CVE-2025-58034, CISA KEV catalog, Fortinet FortiWeb vulnerability, command injection, actively exploited, BOD 22-01, patch management

Reading Time: 6 minutes

Meta Description: CISA has added CVE-2025-58034, a critical and actively exploited command injection vulnerability in Fortinet FortiWeb, to its KEV catalog. Federal agencies must patch within one week.

Article Slug: cisa-adds-exploited-fortinet-fortiweb-flaw-cve-2025-58034-to-kev-catalog

Published Date: Wed, 19 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Wed, 19 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Wed, 19 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: Chicago's St. Anthony Hospital Discloses Data Breach Affecting Over 6,600
item.description:
Headline: Chicago's St. Anthony Hospital Discloses Data Breach Affecting Over 6,600

Summary:
St. Anthony Hospital in Chicago has reported a data breach that may have exposed the personal and medical information of more than 6,600 patients and staff members. The incident, which was discovered in February 2025, occurred when an unauthorized party gained access to several employee email accounts. An investigation revealed that the compromised accounts contained sensitive data, including names, Social Security numbers, medical record numbers, and medical histories. The hospital states there is no evidence the data has been misused but is in the process of notifying all affected individuals.

Severity: Medium

Categories: Data Breach, Phishing, Industrial Control Systems

Article Type: NewsArticle

Keywords: St. Anthony Hospital data breach, healthcare data breach, Chicago hospital breach, patient data exposed, PHI breach, email account compromise

Reading Time: 6 minutes

Meta Description: St. Anthony Hospital in Chicago has disclosed a data breach affecting over 6,600 individuals after employee email accounts were compromised, exposing PII and PHI.

Article Slug: st-anthony-hospital-discloses-data-breach-affecting-6600-individuals

Published Date: Wed, 19 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Wed, 19 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Wed, 19 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: Supply Chain Attacks & AI-Powered Phishing Surge Across Asia-Pacific, Darktrace Warns
item.description:
Headline: Supply Chain Attacks & AI-Powered Phishing Surge Across Asia-Pacific, Darktrace Warns

Summary:
A new threat report from cybersecurity firm Darktrace highlights a dramatic increase in sophisticated cyber threats across the Asia-Pacific and Japan (APJ) region. The report, covering the 12 months to July 2025, details a surge in supply chain attacks, business email compromise, and cloud intrusions. State-sponsored groups from China (APT40, APT41) and North Korea (Lazarus/Bluenoroff) are reportedly leveraging generative AI to create more convincing phishing emails, particularly in non-English languages like Japanese. The report also notes the high cost of supply chain breaches and the use of advanced voice-phishing by groups like Scattered Spider.

Severity: Informational

Categories: Threat Intelligence, Supply Chain Attack, Phishing

Article Type: Report

Keywords: Darktrace report, APJ cybersecurity, supply chain attack, AI phishing, APT40, Lazarus Group, Scattered Spider

Reading Time: 7 minutes

Meta Description: A new Darktrace report reveals a surge in supply chain attacks and AI-enhanced phishing in the Asia-Pacific region, with state-sponsored groups like APT40 and Lazarus leveraging generative AI.

Article Slug: darktrace-report-supply-chain-attacks-and-ai-phishing-escalate-in-apj

Published Date: Wed, 19 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Wed, 19 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Wed, 19 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: China-Aligned APT 'PlushDaemon' Wields 'EdgeStepper' Implant for Network Hijacking
item.description:
Headline: China-Aligned APT 'PlushDaemon' Wields 'EdgeStepper' Implant for Network Hijacking

Summary:
Security researchers have uncovered a new, sophisticated network implant named 'EdgeStepper' used by the China-aligned APT group PlushDaemon. The implant provides the attackers with adversary-in-the-middle (AitM) capabilities, allowing them to intercept and hijack legitimate software updates within a compromised network. EdgeStepper is deployed as part of a larger toolset that includes 'LittleDaemon' and 'DaemonicLogistics' to deliver a Windows implant called 'SlowStepper'. This framework enables the APT group to conduct espionage and deploy additional malware by masquerading as legitimate update traffic.

Severity: High

Categories: Threat Actor, Malware, Supply Chain Attack

Article Type: Analysis

Keywords: PlushDaemon, EdgeStepper, SlowStepper, China APT, adversary-in-the-middle, network implant, ESET research

Reading Time: 7 minutes

Meta Description: Researchers at ESET have discovered 'EdgeStepper,' a new network implant from the China-aligned APT group PlushDaemon, used for adversary-in-the-middle attacks to hijack software updates.

Article Slug: china-aligned-apt-plushdaemon-deploys-edgestepper-network-implant

Published Date: Wed, 19 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Wed, 19 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Wed, 19 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: Togo and Mozambique Forge Cybersecurity Pact to Strengthen African Defenses
item.description:
Headline: Togo and Mozambique Forge Cybersecurity Pact to Strengthen African Defenses

Summary:
The nations of Togo and Mozambique have signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) to formalize their cooperation on cybersecurity. The agreement, signed during the inaugural International Cybersecurity Week in Mozambique, establishes a framework for their national Computer Security Incident Response Teams (CSIRTs) to collaborate. The partnership will focus on sharing real-time threat intelligence, conducting joint capacity-building exercises, and coordinating operational responses to cyber incidents, aiming to bolster the digital resilience of both nations and the wider African continent.

Severity: Informational

Categories: Policy and Compliance, Regulatory, Threat Intelligence

Article Type: NewsArticle

Keywords: Togo Mozambique cybersecurity, Africa cybersecurity, cybersecurity MoU, CSIRT cooperation, threat intelligence sharing Africa

Reading Time: 4 minutes

Meta Description: Togo and Mozambique have signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) to enhance cybersecurity cooperation, including threat intelligence sharing and joint incident response between their national CSIRTs.

Article Slug: togo-and-mozambique-sign-cybersecurity-pact-to-bolster-african-digital-defense

Published Date: Wed, 19 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Wed, 19 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Wed, 19 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

item.title: NEW: Vendor Breach Exposes Patient Data at Innovative Physical Therapy
item.description:
Headline: Vendor Breach Exposes Patient Data at Innovative Physical Therapy

Summary:
Innovative Physical Therapy has notified patients of a data breach that originated from a third-party vendor responsible for practice management. The breach occurred when two vendor employees fell victim to phishing emails, leading to the compromise of their email accounts. Between June 25 and June 26, 2025, an unauthorized party accessed these accounts, which contained the protected health information (PHI) and personally identifiable information (PII) of at least 2,023 patients. The exposed data includes names, Social Security numbers, medical information, and health insurance details.

Severity: Medium

Categories: Data Breach, Supply Chain Attack, Phishing

Article Type: NewsArticle

Keywords: Innovative Physical Therapy data breach, vendor data breach, healthcare supply chain attack, phishing, patient data leak, PHI breach

Reading Time: 6 minutes

Meta Description: Innovative Physical Therapy reports a data breach affecting 2,023 patients after a third-party vendor's employees were compromised by phishing emails, exposing PHI and PII including Social Security numbers.

Article Slug: phishing-breach-at-vendor-exposes-innovative-physical-therapy-patient-data

Published Date: Wed, 19 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Wed, 19 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Wed, 19 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →
